description.narrative: Saferworld is an independent non-governmental organisation active in 15 countries that works to prevent and reduce violent conflict and promote cooperative approaches to security. They work at the intersection between development, conflict and security, focusing on security and justice sector reform, international arms transfer control, SALW, and conflict sensitive approaches to development.

Saferworld är en oberoende NGO som är aktiv i 15 länder och arbetar med att förebygga och reducera våldsamma konflikter och främja samarbetsorienterade angreppssätt till säkerhet. De arbetar i korsningen mellan utveckling, konflikt och säkerhet, och fokuserar på säkerhets- och rättssektorreform, internationella vapenöverföringar, lätta vapen och konfliktkänslighet i utveckling.

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Saferworld works at the intersection of conflict, security and development at both policy and programming levels, focused on 20 conflict-affected contexts across East Africa, Central and South Asia, the Caucasus, Eastern Europe and the Middle East.
Results 2013-2014: - A Community Security Handbook has been developed based on 10 years experiences. - Communities: 42 Community Security action plans were developed and 28 implemented in Nepal (1), Central Asia (7), the Caucasus (8), Kenya (4), South Sudan (8). Teh community sector work was expanded in 11 different conflict contexts in 2013-14. The process of people working together, often in communities with deep ethnic, historical or other divisions, leads to increased trust. These projects address barriers to security and development facing communities, and - through demonstrating that problems can be tangibly addressed – start to increase willingness to engage with authorities and break down feelings of isolation and apathy. - Civil Society: 14 CSOs across 6 regions / countries have demonstrated increased skills, confidence and capacity in issues of community security, conflict-sensitivity, and inclusive governance and political processes: Kosovo,(4) Somalia (3), Sudan (2), South Sudan (2), Somalia (3), Yemen (3). - Authorities: 6 institutions have developed new or strengthened approaches, policies or strategies: Caucasus (2), Kenya (2), Somalia (19, Yemen (1), Nepal (3), South Sudan (2). At least 5 institutions have started to change their practices in line with new strategies / policies / approaches. - External actors who take up SW´s (and partner´s) policy and practice in conflict-affected states: governments (8 - e.g. UK, US, China, South Africa); multilateral organisations (4 -e.g. UN, UN High Level Panel; EU); + INGOs and private sector (China).
Examples of policy achievements: (ii) The adoption of the Arms Trade Treaty by the UN General Assembly, and subsequent signing by Britain and 117 additional states (13 ratifications). SW contributed to achieving this outcome, working in key CSO coalitions, advocating ratification at every opportunity and as contributing experts on numerous bodies, (ii) Significant in-roads into the post-2015 agenda where all of SW’s key asks for the post-2015 framework were taken up in the final HLP report, (iii) SW’s work in China has made importnat progress with uptake among high-level officials, private companies like Sinohydro, and high-ranking Chinese military officers, acknowledging the need to combat diversion of Chinese SALW and ammunition and improve end-use monitoring and verification.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
